channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Trump says he’s reached a trade deal with South Korea ahead of Friday deadline
item.description: The White House did not release details of the arrangement, but the agreement means imports from South Korea will not face new taxes that were set to begin Aug. 1. Deals with other countries, including China and India, remain elusive.

item.title: Kamala Harris will not run for California governor, opening door for 2028 presidential run
item.description: The former vice president’s decision ends speculation over whether she would try to succeed Gov. Gavin Newsom in 2026.

item.title: Army helicopter crew on night of collision with DCA plane had trouble hearing air traffic control, had wrong altitude information
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board began three days of hearings into January’s midair crash near the D.C. area's Reagan National Airport. The hearings — along with the release of almost 10,000 pages of investigative records — should help answer key questions about the deadly incident.

item.title: Federal Reserve keeps interest rates steady but warns about slower economic growth
item.description: The central bank is not in a rush to cut rates, with moderating economic growth and inflation in check so far, the Fed indicated in a statement released Wednesday.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Colleague’s injury seems like a lie to get out of work
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Colleague’s injury seems like a lie to get out of work

item.title: Dining chat: If my server is the owner, should I tip?
item.description: Dining chat: If my server is the owner, should I tip?

item.title: Is it really a ‘massive vibe shift’? George F. Will names the five most misapplied or worn out words today.
item.description: Five words that today are gratingly misapplied or worn out

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein grand jury transcripts include testimony from two law enforcement witnesses, government lawyers say
item.description: That disclosure in a court filing late Tuesday raises questions over whether the Justice Department’s push to unseal those transcripts will satisfy the demand for more information.

item.title: A dispute between neighbors in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Economy grew at a strong 3.0 percent annual pace in the second quarter, a reversal from earlier this year
item.description: The latest snapshot of gross domestic product, the sum of all goods and products in the economy, by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, reflects healthy economic growth in April through June.

item.title: Tsunami warnings. Virginia Giuffre. Climate rules. NYC shooter. Palestinian state. Europe travel fee. Botox. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Top FDA vaccine regulator hired under Trump ousted following conservative criticism
item.description: Vinay Prasad, a physician and former medical professor, joined the administration after gaining prominence as a critic of coronavirus vaccine policies. His ouster follows criticism from conservative activists including Laura Loomer over his approach to drug approvals and past support for Democrats.

item.title: Tsunami alerts issued for U.S. West Coast and Japan after 8.7-magnitude quake in eastern Russia
item.description: The quake ranks in the top 10 strongest earthquakes ever recorded. A tsunami watch is in place for the entire U.S. West Coast, and warnings have been issued in Hawaii and for Japan, where waves as high as 10 feet are forecast.

item.title: Senate confirms controversial Trump nominee Emil Bove as federal judge
item.description: The Senate voted Tuesday night to confirm Emil Bove as a federal appeals court judge, ending a contentious confirmation in which the former attorney for President Donald Trump and top Justice Department official was the target of three whistleblower complaints.

item.title: An op-ed from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent: The road map to making America a crypto superpower
item.description: The road map to making America a crypto superpower

item.title: The U.S. military is investing in this Pacific island. So is China.
item.description: New U.S. radar sites on Palau are designed to keep China in check. But nearby Chinese tourism developments, some with questionable connections, could create vulnerabilities and enable Beijing to disrupt U.S. military activities in the Pacific.

item.title: EPA announces proposal that would end virtually all of its climate regulations
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to rescind a landmark legal opinion that underpins virtually all of its climate regulations, including limits on car and power plant greenhouse gas emissions. EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin said if finalized it would be the largest deregulatory action in U.S. history.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell wants immunity and a copy of House lawmakers’ questions before she testifies, her lawyer says
item.description: The House Oversight Committee has subpoenaed Jeffrey Epstein’s imprisoned associate for a deposition Aug. 11. “Our initial reaction was that Ms. Maxwell would invoke her Fifth Amendment rights and decline to testify at this time,” her attorney wrote in a letter, saying Maxwell would be open to further cooperation if her requests are met.

item.title: Whistleblower suggests Trump judicial nominee Emil Bove misled Senate about his role in dismissed case against NYC Mayor Eric Adams
item.description: A third whistleblower has come forward to challenge the federal judicial nomination of Bove, sharing evidence with lawmakers suggesting the former attorney for President Donald Trump and current top Justice Department official misled lawmakers about his handling of the dismissal of public corruption charges against the New York mayor.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Girlfriend’s fury at partner’s job is so raw they can’t discuss it
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Girlfriend’s fury at partner’s job is so raw they can’t discuss it

item.title: We texted nearly 1,100 Americans about Trump and the Epstein files. Here’s what they said.
item.description: The Washington Post’s poll finds that Americans largely disapprove of how President Donald Trump is handling the issue, with most Democrats and independents disapproving and Republicans expressing a mix of approval and uncertainty. Most Americans strongly support releasing all files in the Jeffrey Epstein case and suspect the documents contain embarrassing information about Trump, Democrats and billionaires.

item.title: A classic villain returns in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Manhattan gunman left note referencing CTE, mayor says; one injured in deadly shooting is an NFL employee
item.description:
Mayor Eric Adams told MSNBC the gunman was not an NFL player but referenced a disease linked to head trauma in a note before killing four people, including a police officer.
NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell said in a staff message that an employee was "seriously injured."

item.title: Manhattan shooting. Epstein poll. Whistleblower claim. Gaza aid. Planned Parenthood. Heat wave. Sydney Sweeney. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Gaza’s death toll passes 60,000, health officials say — a reminder of the human cost of Israel’s war as mass hunger takes hold
item.description: The toll from Gaza’s Health Ministry does not distinguish between civilians and combatants but says the majority of the dead are women and children. Public health experts, doctors and conflict casualty monitors say the official figure is an incomplete count of the total number of people killed in Gaza since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: At least four killed, including an off-duty police officer, in Midtown Manhattan shooting, police say
item.description: The gunman died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, according to the police. The shooting happened inside 345 Park Ave., the tenants of which include the NFL and investment firm Blackstone Group.

item.title: Álvaro Uribe, Colombia’s powerful former president, is convicted in bribery trial
item.description: Álvaro Uribe was found guilty of bribery in criminal proceedings and procedural fraud on Monday, becoming the country’s first former president to be convicted in a criminal trial. The polarizing figure led Colombia from 2002 to 2010 and was credited with turning the tide of his country’s 52-year civil war against leftist insurgents.

item.title: How to reduce your risk of heart disease, according to a cardiologist
item.description: Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. But about 80 percent of cases are considered preventable. There are many things you can do to protect your heart, and here are some evidence-based steps a cardiologist recommends to his patients.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Without explanation, sister-in-law no-shows care for dying mom
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Without explanation, sister-in-law no-shows care for dying mom

item.title: How AI is impacting 700 professions — and might impact yours
item.description: How AI is impacting 700 professions — and might impact yours

item.title: This person ‘will not be intimidated’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: FAA struggles to retain air traffic control recruits in a system with ‘hostile’ training
item.description: One out of five trainees fail to get certified. In some cases, recruits failed their training and were dismissed. In others, they left of their own accord rather than endure what they described as haphazard instruction, organizational dysfunction and abusive conditions. “It’s this professional guild, but to me it also felt like a college hazing,” said a retired FAA psychologist. “It was hostile.”

item.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree to ceasefire after days of border clashes
item.description: The two sides agreed to “an immediate and unconditional ceasefire” starting at midnight, Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said. President Donald Trump had spoken to both leaders to push for peace.

item.title: Gaza aid. Trump-Epstein. E.U. trade deal. Walmart stabbing. Plane evacuation. Walking benefits. Gwyneth Paltrow. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump fumes as Epstein scandal dominates headlines, overshadows his agenda
item.description: The president's exasperation follows weeks of missteps and no clear strategy among top officials who underestimated the outrage, especially from the president’s base, and hoped the country would forget about the unreleased Epstein files and move on, according to nearly a dozen people close to the situation.

item.title: How a microplastics researcher limits exposure to plastics in her day-to-day life
item.description: Scientists have found microplastics in our livers, blood, brains and even placentas. And while more science is needed to fully understand how this affects our health, there’s enough evidence for us to be concerned, writes Tracey Woodruff, a professor at the University of California at San Francisco.

item.title: Tom Lehrer dies at 97. The musician and satirist subverted clichés about romance, patriotism and small-town life.
item.description: His astute social commentary, verbal dexterity and often academic subject matter differentiated him from mere novelty acts during the 1950s and 1960s.

item.title: Trump announces outline of tariff deal with European Union, saying he will impose 15% duty on imports
item.description: Leaders around the world are rushing to strike trade agreements with President Donald Trump ahead of an Aug. 1 deadline, when the White House is expected to begin collecting new tariffs on imports from dozens of countries.

item.title: His son co-piloted the DCA-bound flight that crashed. Now Tim Lilley, also a pilot, is seeking answers.
item.description: Lilley has found himself in two roles. He’s a dad in mourning. He’s also an aviation expert — one who has flown both types of aircraft in the Jan. 29 collision at Reagan National Airport — focused on finding answers and accountability for the families of all 67 people killed in the crash.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Tour de France confronts a new threat: Are cyclists using tiny motors?
item.description: After a doping scandal, professional cycling is pursuing the dual challenges of keeping the sport honest and convincing a skeptical audience it is.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Israel allows airdrops of food into Gaza amid international pressure over mounting starvation
item.description: The first pallets of flour, sugar and canned food were dropped late Saturday. A growing number of foreign governments, including Jordan and Britain, have volunteered to airdrop food into Gaza to relieve a deepening crisis that has included deaths from starvation. Aid workers have said the approach is inefficient and inadequate to what's needed.

item.title: Hegseth team told to stop using polygraph tests to root out people leaking to news media after complaint to White House
item.description: The White House directed Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to cease the use of polygraph tests after a senior adviser to Hegseth complained to senior officials about being targeted, U.S. officials and others familiar with the matter said.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: Roommate reacts with ‘bafflement and confusion’ every time I vent
item.description: Ask Sahaj: Roommate reacts with ‘bafflement and confusion’ every time I vent

item.title: A timeless Chinese game is hooking people across D.C. and the nation
item.description: Interest in mah-jongg is surging, thanks in part to a coterie of coaches and instructors, social media influencers, and luxe spaces to play.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: From David Ignatius: The 12 days that turned back the clock on Iran’s nuclear program
item.description: Israeli and American assessments agree Tehran’s infrastructure to finish a bomb is shattered.

item.title: Federal judge dismisses Trump administration lawsuit against Illinois and Chicago over 'sanctuary city' policies
item.description: District Judge Lindsay C. Jenkins ruled that the Justice Department "lacks standing" to sue the state and city over what the White House has characterized as impeding its efforts to crack down on undocumented immigrants.

item.title: Trump administration releases billions it withheld from school programs, ending weeks of educators’ anxiety before academic year
item.description: With the school year beginning in just weeks, lawmakers of both parties had lobbied the administration to release the funds, which support English-language learning programs, teacher training and academic enrichment.
